The first shoujo anime I ever watched was Sailor Moon. I was around 6 and I would watch the show with my older sister every Saturday morning. I didn’t understand plot elements, the romance, all the jokes, but I do remember having a great time and it being a fond memory. I will admit that since childhood, I have not watched many shoujo anime. In fact I have a tendency to avoid shoujo anime. The esoteric world of shoujo, with it’s soft color pastels, large eyes, bishounen protagonists are all foreign to me. I often find I get bored, busy, or drop the show infavour of a show I find more interesting. However Ore Monogatari has proven to be an exception. Every Wednesday I searched for the subbed episode and found myself watching Ore Monogatari before all other anime. In the shower I would sing the protagonist’s catch phrase, “I love her” in the style of “Uptown Funk” by Mark Ronson. I would chat on skype and other formats expressing my love for the show. The show just felt so different, so fresh to many of us. However one day I spoke to an anime fan who has seen a great deal of shoujo, she admitted that she didn’t understand my fascination with the show. She stated that the show may not be as groundbreaking and different that I thought it was. I wrote this review as a way to explore my own opinions and thoughts about this series, I hope it is a benefit both to you and me. 



Characters


The reason why I felt this anime was so different was because of the protagonist, Gouda Takeo. In the opening of the show there is a scene of Takeo atop the Empire State Building, an allusion to King Kong. Takeo is similar to King Kong in that he is enormous, his size causes others to fear him and to misunderstand him, but beneath that scary exterior lies a heart of gold. It is only when people get to know Takeo better, do they start to realize how great of a person he is. Going back to the Sailor Moon reference, the male lead Tuxedo Mask is a handsome, mysterious, bishounen type character, everything Takeo is not which I found refreshing. There is a complaint that Takeo is far too simplistic of a character. Some find this annoying, but others like myself find it endearing. No matter how many times Takeo said “I love her,” I never once found it annoying because I felt the character was being genuine to himself.


Besides Takeo the other main leads are Yamato and Suna. Suna is Takeo’s good looking best friend and Yamato is the girl Takeo loves. The three characters have great chemistry with one another. Perhaps some of the best moments are when Suna and Takeo play off one another. The two complement each other so well with Takeo being very blunt and direct while Suna being more reserved and laid back. The anime spent time to show their history in the form of flashbacks. Usually I am not a fan of flashbacks but some of these flashbacks were so funny and cute that they were a joy to watch. The flashbacks also helped to make these characters feel more real and genuine. I would classify Yamato as being a “girly girl” who is very cute and reminds me of a rabbit with large eyes. As a love interest she would be any person’s ideal. However as a stand alone character she is far less interesting. The only thing I know about her that is not related to Takeo is she is a good at making desserts. With so much time and emphasis being placed on exploring the background of Takeo and Suna, I would have liked to have learned more about the female lead.



Story


This is where Ore Monogatari falls flat. I have begrudgingly acknowledged that aside from Takeo not being a bishounen lead, Ore Monogatari appears to follow the standard shoujo format I have come to expect. The male leads saves the female lead from being groped on a train, romance ensues. It is always Takeo who saves the day with Yamato or her friends being a damsel in distress. The conflict of whether Takeo gets the girl, gets resolved very early in the series. This is a 24 episode series, after that initial conflict nothing much if anything happens. Instead the show begins to shift focus on secondary characters and simple misunderstandings between the leads. I did enjoy some of these shifts in focus, but in a 24 episode series I would expect more focus to be placed on the leads themselves. Especially when this anime is named “My Love Story!!”.


I feel the main problem with the leads are that they are too perfect. Takeo may not be the ideal boyfriend but he always does the right thing and Yamato is the perfect girlfriend. This makes the show fairly predictable even in the finale. However in a real relationship people are not always perfect, they fight, they argue. Simple misunderstandings tend to evolve into something more serious. It can be argued that this romance anime is meant to portray young, teenage love and that the two have not reached a sour point in their relationship. That is fine, however the fact remains that this is a 24 episode series, there is opportunity for more than just budding love. 


Ore Monogatari reminds me of a one shot romance manga. For those unfamiliar, a one shot manga is a manga with only one chapter. I make this comparison because I feel as though Ore Monogatari does not have enough substance to warrant it being a 24 episode series, it could have easily been cut down to 12. Lastly I will say that I strongly identified with Takeo’s struggles of having a low self esteem, thinking you are worthless, placing others ahead of one’s self. It was one of the reasons why I first loved this anime. However this theme is only brought up in the beginning and ending of this anime, this theme is so strong that I wish they would have brought it up more. This and other dark moments of the show are when I felt the most engaged. However the show brushes off many of these moments and never addresses them again. 



Art/Animation


The style very much follows the standard art conventions of shoujo anime. Soft colour palette, characters with large eyes, Suna looking like the typical bishounen character. I would be lying if I said there was anything extraordinary or different when it comes to art and animation. I will say it is all very fitting, the whole point of this artstyle is to give a sense of warmth and feeling of Kawaii, and that is exactly what it gave me. The cutest parts are the inner monologues some characters have, where their thoughts and feelings get physically manifested by cute little drawings. The artstyle is noticeably simplistic, and some scenes feel washed out.  It is almost as though the show is run through one filter when some scenes would do better without it. In regards to the characters designs, Takeo is huge and Yamato is petite. When the two are together their physical characteristics are highlighted. For example when Takeo and Yamato hold hands, her hand looks at though it were a baby’s hand next to his. There was a joke made by one of Yamato’s friends about how they would kiss. When I picture it in my head I can’t help but laugh, I keep picturing Takeo’s enormous lips and I wonder how exactly it would work. My point is, I wonder if the character designs inhibits the anime from being taken very seriously. I get that Takeo is drawn this way to play up the laughs, but perhaps it is a double edged sword. 



Sound 


I feel as though this is Ore Monogatari’s most overlooked aspect. I would describe the musical score as being subtle and whimsical with a soundtrack that at times can be flat out gorgeous. The group responsible for the musical score and soundtrack is S.E.N.S, the duo also did the music for Kimi Ni Todoke which has a similar feel to this series. However I would say this is a vast improvement mainly due to the added orchestral elements to this soundtrack. Often a track starts with a simple melody on the piano or guitar but then orchestral instruments like the violin, harp and flute fill in the empty spaces. Many tracks like “Story of Mind”, swell to a climax that allows the listener to succumb to a state of euphoria. The issue is that the musical score for this anime mostly uses that first thirty seconds in a track where it is often fairly simplistic. There are tracks like “Hurry Up” and “Dull” where I had to take off my headphones and make sure I was listening to the right soundtrack. At a certain point songs can get very complex with many underlying tones. I understand that the score has to fit the anime and the producers wanted the show to have a warm simplistic feel, however I do feel bad for S.E.N.S. because it feels as though many of their efforts had gone to waste. There must have been a better way of incorporating this beautiful soundtrack into the score. 


This is a romantic comedy and S.E.N.S were able to make the comedic score not sound juvenile by using Takeo’s physical and mental characteristics. An example of this is the song “Eye of the TAKEO” which is an allusion to Eye of the Tiger from Rocky III, however sounds more like Rocky’s theme from the original Rocky film. Takeo is often compared to a gorilla and S.E.N.S play this up by producing tracks like “Clumsy” and “Health First” that sound like they could come from a Donkey Kong video game; they even subtly incorporate 8 bit music to the track. The one aspect I wish the soundtrack and score used more of were jazz tracks which I thought would complement the tone of the show perfectly.


The voice acting was very fitting however I will say that some voices can be polarizing. What can seem very cute and sweet to one person can sound very annoying to another. An example of this is Yamato’s high toned voice that has a very distinct accent. I would like to give a special hand to Takuya Eguchi who is the voice of Takeo as well as Hachiman from Yahari Ore No Seishun Love Comedy. These two characters couldn’t be more different both in voice and characteristics which helps to emphasize Eguchi’s range as a voice actor.  



Conclusion


Characters: 6/10

Story: 4/10

Art/Animation: 6/10

Sound: 7/10 (Would be higher if they could have used the soundtrack better)

Enjoyment: 8/10

Overall: 6/10


While Takeo is looked down upon by many females of the show, every male character who meets Takeo loves him. Takeo is manly, great at sports, all the girls don’t fawn over him, honest, loyal and always has your back. Someone you want to be friends with. I think that is why so many guys I have talked to, including me, fell in love with this show. We do not want to see some pretty boy have all the girls fall in love with him and also get the female lead. We relate to Takeo’s struggles of self esteem, not being incredibly handsome and being awkward around girls. That is why I feel that Ore Monogatari is a great introduction to shoujo for many male fans who like me were initially wary of the genre. I have heard of other great shoujo shows and now I want to explore the genre more. I think this show is perfect for couples out there to watch together. I see tons of articles like “Chick Flicks Your Boyfriend Will Love”, I feel this would be the anime equivalent of a movie on that list. The show does have it’s faults, flat characters, lack of plot progression, repetitiveness, reliance on tropes, however the characters are so endearing that many of these faults can be overlooked. That being said endearment can be polarizing, if you don’t enjoy this anime 3 episode in I would recommend you to drop it.

This anime has a very realistic storyline. I think that the author of this anime was trying to convey the message that love can be found anywhere. However, as much as I enjoyed the realism of this story, I did not like the characters.
I liked where the author was going with this series, saying that there is hope in finding love for everyone. However, I watch anime to escape the reality of the world and indulge myself in the senseless harem romances, where the perfect guy can get whatever he wants. The male does not have to be perfect at all, at least smart andsensible. In this anime, Takeo had a senseless mind. His mind was always somewhere else or only fixed on one thing. He was a simple minded character that had almost no appeal to the general audience.


When I first picked up this series and watched the first episode, I thought that the story was good enough for me to continue watching but it quickly got boring as there was no direction to the plot. By this point, I was hoping for Sunakawa would have slowly developed his own kingdom of women or at least gotten a single girlfriend. I continued watching, but to no prevail. He seems very capable and would be a likable main character for the majority of the audience, but his selfless personality over-shone the main character, Takeo, yet still did not get the kind of action that I expected.


As a note, even the supporting characters had some sort of love blossom throughout the series, but the second main lead did not get anything. I ended up giving up on this series towards the end and began to skip parts and skim through the episodes. Lo and behold!!!... I won't say anything more to prevent spoilers. If you want to watch it for the same reason I watched it, SUFFER AS WELL!! MWA HAHAHAH!!


ANYWAYS, overall, this was a good story to follow but it had no direction. If this was a 12 episode series, or even a 6 episode series, I would have been more than satisfied.

Warning possible Spoilers
Pretty much the whole point of this anime is that size and appearance doesn't matter to a persons heart and in my eyes that is amazing.
The story centres around Takeo Gouda who is one big, tall and clumsy guy who hasn't had much luck with the ladies whereas his best friend gets all the ladies until one day Takeo meets Rinko Yamato and his luck finally changed for the better.
I really enjoyed the story even though it doesn't have a end goal it is mainly about the relationship between Takeo and Rinko in their everyday lives and I generally thought this was anice and relaxing story to enjoy which it was, it was very enjoyable to watch.

There was a lot of other sub-plots that did happen along the way which would challenge Takeo's and Rinko's relationship like other people who had crushes on them, stuff that happens with each other's families and even situations that had something to do with their friends or being in dangerous situations like being in a building fire or trapped in the woods it generally felt like a fun adventure with these guys, But the one concern I had with the story is that during the final 4 episodes the feeling I had from the start suddenly started to dip I don't know if it was because of the situations that happened in these episodes or something else, but other than that I really enjoyed the story.


Now the characters were really fun to watch seeing the relationship between Takeo and Rinko is probably one of the most adorable things I've seen even though they are completely different size's and height's they fit so well together plus they never really go though any bad stuff that many other anime couples go through for once it just decided to go for the fun and happy route and it was on hell of a ride seeing these characters get past obstacles in their relationship like holding hands, first kiss, supporting each other when either one is doing something that is difficult for them it was very sweet seeing these two go through this stuff.

But that doesn't mean the other characters don't shine too, Makoto who is Takeo's best friend is probably one of the best, best friend characters that I have seen because even though he is really monotone he generally cares for Takeo and gives him helpful advice with his relationship with Rinko, Makoto's sister was another interesting character because she actually had a crush on Takeo when they were both younger, but of course she had lost her chance and instead of going against Rinko she decides to help them both out while also having to take care one of her own problems and this showed she was a very thoughtful person.

There was also a sub-plot between Takeo's and Rinko's group of friends and it was also interesting seeing them develop because at first they weren't really interested then over time they slowly grew to like each other so it was fun seeing other characters develop other than Takeo and Rinko.


I really liked the artstyle it resembled Your Lie in April which is why I thought this show looked beautiful most of the time and it used speech bubbles like you see in comics or manga's which were used to show the characters inner thought's which felt different and unique for once since I haven't seen another anime do this before or since.


This was another anime that had food as a big focus of the anime, but it was sweet and funny seeing Takeo's reactions to Rinko's many desserts or sweets that she gave to him over the course of the show, the comedy in this show was golden I hardly stopped laughing it was that good and there is some love triangles introduced at certain points, but I thought these were actually good because it tested the strength of Takeo and Rinko's relationship.


Overall I thought this anime was adorable and very entertaining if you're looking for a sweet and funny Romance for once instead of a tragic one then watch this it'll definitely leave you laughing by the end.

It's a 24-episode series adapted from the shoujo manga of the same name.
Just letting it out there--this isn't the kind of anime that's meant to be thought-provoking, or be set up with a cast of complex and multidimensional characters with multiple plot twist. What we have here is, instead, a simple love story between two nicely fleshed out characters, with just enough introduction of conflicts and interesting minor characters to keep things interesting.
Story is  dead simple--boy meets girl. That's all there is to it. There are trials and tribulations, but it's relatively minor, and there aren't really any gut punches that will keep youreeling like some animes do. Minor plot points involving characters other than main 3 characters are also interesting and do not feel like after thoughts. But again, it's not complex. Story is not--and is not meant to be--engaging.


Art is outstanding, with the style that I am a fan of. You can see some cut corners occasionally, but that's the norm and I wouldn't take any points off because it's not very glaring. Nice use of budget.


But budget took a hit in terms of sound--OP is literally played everywhere. But I guess that's the norm, too. But variety would've been nice.


Characters are quite likable, aside from those that obviously shouldn't be. But even unlikable characters seem to have a habit of turning around. This is a feel-good anime and it sticks to its mission. Depth is lacking, and even the deepest, darkest secrets... tend not to be. Closest thing to revelations are probably backstories.


I enjoyed the show greatly. I wasn't in the mood for anything heavy and this fit the bill to a T. I wouldn't recommend it to someone looking for adult-y cyberpunk-y over the top grimdark anime that we sometimes have a kick for. Watch it when you want to feel warm and fuzzy, with enough humor to keep you laughing, to boot.

Just because someone's friend is a nice person doesn't mean they're nice too. Sometimes, they're friends because the person's nice enough to have them. 
-Makoto Sunakawa
Why is it that things are so important, like feelings, hearts, and souls, are things you can never see?
-Gouda Takeo
Story:
Gouda Takeo, a freshfolk in high school really wants a girlfriend. But since Takeo isn't skinny and hot, so none of the girls find him attractive. They're always wanting to fall for his sexy friend, Makoto Sunakawa. One day while Makoto and Takeo are on the train home, Takeo prevents a groper from messing from this girl. Her name is RinkoYamato, and Takeo and Yamato fall in love. <3

    That's mostly it.


Characters:

Takeo - He was hilarious and just the fun, gigantor the guys in his class loved to hang out with. Although like most dudes, Takeo was dense, but he always put other's feelings in front of his and did things that would hurt him, but made others happy.


Makoto - Seriously, he was my favorite character. Makoto was this really chill dude that's been Takeo's BFF from the start. Even though they're ying and yang, they get along very well. Makoto was the guy that gave Takeo all the dating advice, although he's never tried it out himself.


Yamato - She's cute, bubbly, and very clumsy. Yamato was the steriotypical girly-girl-I-care-about-you-lovey-dovey sort of way, and that's good.


Ai (Makoto's older sister) - Ai was pretty good too. She was this dramatic but caring college girl that secretly had a crush on Takeo, but eventually helped Yamato with Takeo.


Oda - This guy looked like Makoto's twin, but with funky hair. Oda had an obsessive crush on Ai and started to be her tail. Takeo helped him on his love path and Ai was like, "screw it, let's date."


Amami - !Yandare alert! This nerd had a seriously creepy crush on Makoto for 10 years. 10 YEARS SHE WAS STALKING HIM... Finally Amami came out of the corner and asked Makoto out, and I'm not telling you the results.


Maki (Takeo's baby sister) - This kid was mentioned more in the manga when Makoto was all like, "oh, I'll go away because Takeo doesn't need me anymore" and stuff. Maki is this overweight adorable baby that Takeo is about in love with (so is Yamato). 


Art:

The art was very good. Some points in the episode when up close, you could see the characters were heavily inked which I loved. The colors fit the characters well, like giving Ichinose darker colors (being hot guy #2) and Makoto lighter colors (being hot guy #1). I liked how they made both the Sunakawas dress similar with bright, but not outgoing, colors.


Music:

At first, I absolutely HATED the opening. But at the last episodes, I savored the tune starting from the "My Christmas" episode because who knows why. The sound effects of people running were very overdone like in most anime. Yamato would run for 3 seconds and she'd act like she'd run a marathon or something by panting dramatically. 


I thought Ore Mongatari was hilarious and an anime that lightened up my day. I'd pop it on and laugh along with Makoto and Takeo all day long. I'm not sure if the anime got a lot of likes, but it's a romance, so...??

One perverted request was that I wish they'd gotten more involved in the love and dating part like some henta- ok, I'll stop there.....


MOVIE:

They screwed it... They screwed everything!!!! Ai wasn't even mentioned! Neither was the Yandare girl or the pastry guy!!! 

I didn't appreciate that more than half that movie was Takeo still thinking that Yamato like Makoto. It was infuriating to not see more of Takeo x Yamato. And the whole fire thing? You'd think it happened at MM Land from the looks of it. And I think it would've been better if they kept that one of the girls was trapped inside the building and such. It wouldn't affect Takeo and Yamato's relationship because you could clearly see that wasn't going anywhere. Also, the scene with Takeo and his father looking at the stars, what happened to Takeo, Yamato, and Makoto doing that?

One other thing I'll comment on is that they talked SO slowly. Even in the anime they kept up in conversation and didn't have to pause every 2 words.  

I appreciate the fact they didn't make Yamato's voice over-the-top-3-year-old because that got on my nerves (although I got used to it). But god was that ending weird....

If you like sweet stories and happy people, you'll probably like this. If you like some meat to your animes or something that challenges what you hold to be true, this will not succeed. Watching Ore Monogatari is like someone taking a soft, blow-up hammer and hitting you over the head with it while feeding you cake and telling you "Don't judge people by looks, trust the people you care about and work hard to be your best self"
It's not a bad message by any means and there are worse things in the world than a show that gives off an aura of sweetness andhappiness. That's about where it stops, though.

Okay, I'm gonna start this review off by telling you that I've never written a review before and that I'm incapable of giving concrete ratings for art, sound, character etc.
The main reason that I felt like writing a review for this is the fact that I've never before watched a shoujo anime (nor read many shoujo manga). But this should be an exception.
Normally I am, just like many guys, scared off by the label 'shoujo'. Mainly because of the fact that many romance shoujo anime are (in my eyes) all pretty much the same. Now please don't freak out, because this can be said formany, many shounen anime as well. But I personally feel that this anime is different. One of the reasons for this is that the main character of this anime is a guy, which is something that's a must for me. And when I heard that Ore Monogatari had Takeo, a guy, as main character, I immediately started off by reading the manga first. And to be honest, I fell in love with it. After reading the manga I began with the anime. Which, at the time, was already at like 18 episodes. And for the first time in a long time I practically marathoned those 18 episodes.


One of the main reasons I loved this is because of the fact that it doesn't feel like a shoujo anime. A male main character, who isn't all pretty and sparkly all shoujo style, but the exact opposite. That drew me to instantly liking Takeo. Even the other guys in the anime (who, mind you, are drawn shoujo style) didn't give me the 'prince on a white horse' generic shoujo character impression. So all in all if someone were to ask me which audience (shounen or shoujo) this anime is watchable for, I would without a doubt say both.


One of the few things which I personally found a bit too much was the innocence of the love. In certain amounts it's good, but for me this was too much. They hold hands like they're both walking naked on the streets and the first name basis is like doing it for the first time. Which annoyed me a little bit, but not enough to even hesitate to be excited for the next episode.



So, for all the guys asking if this is watchable despite being shoujo: Abso-freaking-lutely.

Many would call this anime predictable and boring, but although it can be those things it also has a lot of heart. I can sense the character's personalities straight away and enjoyed the light that they projected even from a computer screen. I feel that these characters had a lot more life than what is usually seen in anime and I suppose emotionally I became instantly attached. The storyline is a bit slow, but progression is there and it is wonderful to see a girl push for what she wants in an anime. Although shy and a bit odd, Yamato-san is a sweet girl thatis definitely relatable on many levels. Takeo-kun is a dependable and overall honorable guy that you quickly grown to love. Suna is definitely my favorite character from the whole show and definitely the greatest of bros. Overall, although unrealistic in some ways, the show had heart and for that it gets an 8 in my books. Perhaps not the most professional review but the music was nice enough, the animation was good enough and the plot points were sweet. The show didn't break boundaries or form unique situations but it did show a lot of emotion. I think at times in television shows or movies we become so worried about the technical standpoints and whether or not we learned anything. I think what the show proves is that it's okay to sit back and simply enjoy and feel joy. I definitely recommend this anime if you are having a sad day or simply want to watch a cute romance. The show does it pretty well. :)

To put it simply, this anime has exceeded my expectations greatly. It made me laugh and smile (+ I shed a few tears as well). I would have given this a perfect score if not for a few flaws that I will elaborate on later. This is pretty spoiler-free, so read on with ease.
Story
Okay, it's not that original.. but it's still pretty refreshing. Most love stories I've seen in anime are pretty drawn-out and are focused on the chasing part of the relationship (a.k.a the part where they refuse to confess to each other etc) and they get pretty boring after like thousands of episodeswith the MCs still saying dumb stuff like "I don't love him/her!!!" ...This is where Ore Monogatari is different. The 'chase' is much shorter in this anime as compared to others and  is more focused on the actual relationship. Some people in the reviews are unhappy about this and claim that the series should have ended right there (which I can understand) and everything afterwards is sooooOooO boring (which I can't as much), but honestly, the relationship between Takeo and Yamato + the friendship between Takeo and Suna are too cute to resist. Of course, the story does get VERY repetitive after a while, so if you're a person who craves for a action-packed storyline, this anime definitely isn't for you. However, I personally enjoyed it as watching them living happy lives (with occasional obstacles) makes me happy as well (cheeesy). :))

____


Art

It's all really colourful and beautiful. I don't have any complaints. (Plus, the way they portray Takeo's dramatic expressions at times is so funny that I can't help but laugh)

____


Sound

I love the OP and ED songs; both are very catchy. The seiyuus for the characters were pretty appropriate too, in my opinion. 

____


Character

Pretty much the main reason why I love this anime so much is the lovable characters (well, the main characters). Takeo is such a selfless, brave, strong and kind person, Yamato is a sweet, caring and hardworking person and Suna is kind, understanding, gives great advice and is always there for people. Instead of the usual love triangle we see in many love stories, Suna is happy to see both of them together and is not jealous in the slightest (or at least, that is how he is portrayed to be). The friendships and relationships are all very genuine and heartwarming, which is what I value in an anime. With these friendships and relationships, the characters have developed quite a bit as well (mainly Takeo and Yamada). A flaw would be that the side characters did not have that much character development... but then again, the manga is ongoing, so let's hope that there will be some in the future.

____


Overall

I enjoyed watching the whole series very much. The comedy, relationships and friendships kept me going :) Feel free to give it a watch if you're into the plot! It will most likely not disappoint. I'd recommend you to drop it if you're not into it by the third episode, though.

There are hundreds of slice of life rom-com anime out there. What stood out about Ore Monogatari is that the story is so light but for some reason it puts you at the edge of your seat because of the anticipation of seeing how relationships would develop over the next episodes. 
The "gorilla-like" character has been a staple at mangas and anime in order to create a comic relief or to emphasize how attractive  the main character is by creating a contrast. Ore Monogatari is different. The "gorilla-like" character was the main focus of the story which is such a breath of fresh air.His appearance was always being brought up but honestly, I didn't care that he looked so out of place as a main character because I was so hooked at the entire show as a whole. 


Aside from the twist on the regular prince type protagonist, the story was pretty much straight forward. It's about Gouda Takeo's love story and his daily interaction with the people around him. I also ADORED how the anime didn't only focus on the romantic aspect love, half of it was about friendship too. Speaking of friendship, can we all take a moment t appreciate Suna and Takeo's bromance? I was so affected by their friendship, it just felt so sincere (yes, I'm aware, it's an anime). 


The show was filled with endearing characters, all of them have their own quirks which makes them so interesting. In my opinion, Takeo was the one with the most character development, he started as a gentle giant of a push over and ended up being more reliable and confident. Next up was Suna, I thought for sure he would be made into a 1-dimensional uninteresting eye candy but I was wrong. He was still the prince type. Intelligent, cool headed, quiet, perceptive and kind. The fact that Suna, the conventional protagonist type, didn't overshadow Gouda, the "gorilla-like" side character type was praise worthy. The one who stayed consistent throughout the show (in a good way) was Yamato, she's the cookie-cutter heroine, kind, cheerful, positive, smart, good at baking but she's not the pure clueless type (in you know what I mean). To sum up her character, she's very relatable. 


Final thoughts?! God damn, the hype about this anime is well deserved. It's a feel-good hilarious show. I wish there will be a second season, and I want it to be about Suna. Suna's Love Story to be exact. I think it'd be interesting to watch Suna fumbling around trying to figure out love and relationship. Now if you'll excuse me, I'll go look for the manga now.

Ore Monogatari is the ‘500 Days of Summer’ of Anime. ‘This is not a love story. This is a story about love.’ That is the tagline of 500 DoS. Starting out as a love story, Ore Monogatari tells the tales of various characters that appear and how love has an effect on their lives. All of this is seen through the eyes of Takeo Gouda, the Big Show with a kind heart. 
Strengths
The biggest strength of Ore Monogatari!! is the interpersonal relationships between the various characters, particularly Takeo’s relationship with the side cast. After the first 3 episodes that revolve around Takeo meeting Rinko Yamato,his love interest, the series delves into primarily 2 episode stories that detail each side character’s problem and resolution. Each character wants love and, through their journey of finding romance, they develop into a better person after their story arc is complete, some more than others. These stories stem from Takeo’s best friend Makoto Sunakawa facing problems in his family to Takeo’s other classmates tackling their own romantic problems. Each character’s stories are what keep Ore Monogatari entertaining in its 24-episode span, including the one-off episodes centered on the goofball duo of Takeo and Rinko. 


The animation and music is bright, colorful and upbeat. Words can’t describe how good the show looks and sounds. Studio Madhouse did an excellent job adapting this story.


Misstep

Possibly both the best and weakest part about Ore Monogatari!! is Takeo and Rinko. Takeo and Rinko are the least complex characters of the entire cast, and because of that, they are possibly the least interesting characters of their own show. After the initial three episodes, the primary roles for the two, aside from lighthearted, fluffy romance, is helping each side character in their story arcs. In other words, Takeo and Rinko play more of a supportive role. It is unfortunate that the side characters overshadow the main characters. However, it is never tiring to see Takeo and Rinko’s lighthearted romance portrayed on screen. 


Overall

Ore Monogatari!! is SUPER vanilla, meant to warm the ice cold of hearts. Even though they are the least interesting characters compared to the side cast, Takeo and Rinko are good characters that serve as the audience’s identification figures. The show is lighthearted and straightforward with a touch of character complexities that have possibilities to be delved into further.

Alright, this show is far from a masterpiece. It's cliched, occasionally pretty dumb, and admittedly very, very cheesy. If you've seen pretty much any other rom-com anime, you can imagine how this plays out. Despite this, it's still a very enjoyable experience. 
This series is packed full of quirky humor that perfectly accompanies it's visual art and musical style. More importantly, this is one of the very few romances of any medium that I've seen that doesn't feel disingenuous. While the side characters are often fairly weak, our leads, Takeo and Yamato, have an easily likable chemistry that pops out from the first episode. Samegoes for the relationship Takeo has with Sunakawa, his childhood friend. Also, it is incredibly refreshing to watch an anime without any ecchi fanservice. \n
As I mentioned before, it's far from a masterpiece, but if you're looking for a cute, light-hearted, slice-of-life anime that always delivers a satisfying ending, I'd recommend it.

Ore Monogatari hit home for me. Way out of the field, nothing to even consiitor, it just won. It takes thestory of two friends that have known eachother since their kindergarden days and puts them in a world full of ramance. It rellates both characters to the japanese nursery story of the red ogre and the blue ogre, one wants to make friends so the other makes a commention to show the people that the first is not a bad guy. I feel they hit very key points everywhere, leaving me utterly astonished by how they ended it so perfectly.
I feel the sound needs tobe hit first since it was just LOVELY. I was blown away by how perfect every voice actor matched their character and their roles. Each voice held its weight to the love and it clearly showed that each actor had a good feel for these roles, making me want to hear them again in the future for whatever anime they might be casted in. Now the bgm, that... that stuff was something else. Honestly, I got so involved in the anime that I completely ignpored the bgm often enough that I didn't actually think there was any but when I started listening to it, I was very impressed. The intro song will forever be ingraved in my mind. It was one of the most catchy, love-feely intro I've heard in a long time and after trying to watch episode 4 without it, the anime didn't feel complete. 


Shoujo art has a very unique and awe filled art style that emphisises on the love and the emotions in the characters face that you just don't normally get from other animes or art style, or even a lot of real TV. Yes, shoujo art is very one sided, eaither you love it or you hate it. I feel ORe Monogatari did somethere with that that a lot of other animes are trying so hard to do these days; they went right out with its art and pretty much said "if you like shoujo art, this anime is gonna blow your mind because its gonna have all the art feels you need!" and completely ignored trying to appaise those that don't like shoujo, which in turn, may not get them as many viewers, but it definatly makes it a show that highly appeases those that like shoujo. The array of colors used for the characters was very nice and it made each character feel alive, while still give that 2-D feel that we all love. Now the one issue I did have with the art, was that it never looked the same twice. Proeportioning issues where everyone between height diffences, which did make me a little confused here and there.


Each character had their own way of working their way into your heart, weither it be through force or by -dereing its way it. Even watching a second character get turned down, and loving the main girl, it just broke me up when anyone got rejected at anytime during this anime. I do wish the characters had more background and had more of a story to tell, but I feel they hit the relationship developments extrordinarily well. The fact that we only get to meat the MC's parents was kidn of a let down to be honest, as I would have loved to see an episode where the hero meets the Heroine's parents.


Plot devolpment in this anime was instintanious. There was no buffer, there was no wait, you knew exactly how the anime was gonna felt from the first episode. Or atleast thats what I thought after seeing. Making this anime actually have a main topic for the MC instead of his struggle TO get that #1 person was a brilliant idea. Showing the soft side of a giant MC is always a great idea and giving the assertive role to the heroine was jaw dropping. Throught the story, I felt that everything progressed astonishingly well and kept me involved and wanting more each minute. 


The feels this anime gave me were on par only with Your Lie In April and even then, I feel it can't even begin to compair to them because Ore Monogatari just had such a strong way to show that it was it's onw style of romance and had too much going for it to be just another shoujo romance. I enjoyed every part of this anime and enjoyed every aspect of the director's ideals for these characters. Overall, its just too good to pass up for anyone. I feel it has to be watched.

[This review will focus on finding out if this anime is worth a shot for YOU]
{For starters, this is a very very heart-melting anime, so if you're very, say, "sensitive" to very very cute and (sort of) exaggerated lovey-dovey scenes, you'll probably even cringe watching Ore Monogatari!, or at least find it too cheesy.
 But honestly, I don't think many people are like this, but in case you are, there are many other Romance anime for you to try. I'd suggest True Tears or Toradora!, but you can look it up yourself. 
For me to say the above, I don't mean that Ore Monogatari istoo cheesy or anything, it is just VERY heart warming.} 


Next, I'll explain what you should be expecting from this anime(also considering you like romance):


>A relationship with a constrast between a very cute short girl (Yamato)and a 2 meter tall, very kind hearted guy(Takeo), both first year high-schoolers.


>A very episodic-based series, showing many experiences in the first step into the world of love relationships between these two.

>Many of the stories are honestly real-life relatable, others not a lot, but still very amazing and heart-warming.


>VERY VERY heart-melting reactions (sorry I just can't emphasize this enough) from the characters, that sometimes might even make you think something like: "Oh God, I know this feeling so well! " or even simply "This is actually relatable! " and lol at the situations 


>The classic best friend of the guy in the relationship(Suna), who helps him, and even her, see things from an outsider's perspective to help them solve their problems. This character really really stood out for me because, again, this is very relatable to the real world and makes up for so many satisfying episodes.


>Not a definite storyline, just an episodic and pure slice-of-life anime, constantly showing how the couple is always thinking one abut the other, how they tend to hide some things now and then, just like true human beings.


>Takeo's personality will overwhelm you, and Yamato's as well, since neither of them think twice before sacrificing their well-being for the other's happiness



So, if you are prepared for a """cheesy""" anime, with absolutely adorable and relatable situations in the world of high school love, then this anime suits you!

IMPORTANT: when i say """"cheesy"""" i just mean that the anime is just constantly throwing cutesy and lovely scenes to your face, which some people may consider to be cheesy

OreMonogatari!! (My Story!!) is a light hearted shoujo rom-com that i liked a lot.
First, the comedy is very well made. I mean, i laughed a lot at some points... and i'm not the type that laugh a lot... so this could explain itself how i found good the comedy in this anime.
Second, the romance. Well, it's the classic dream type romance story. Who wouldn't like to have a girlfriend like Yamato? Or a boyfriend like Taeko? I mean, they're pretty unusual, but they're great. I think that everyone would fall for them. 
But, anyways, it's good and enjoyable. 
Third, and this part is my andonly my opinion. This anime reminded my life. I'm not strong or tall as Taeko but everytime people look at me like, they think that i'm a bad guy. (And when they begin to talk to me, they smile 'cause i'm nice... i would never understand the human mind.) \n
So i felt Taeko stronger, i felt his insecurity, his thoughts. But he's nice, kind and sweet. And first of all, he's sincere with others. \n
Let's return at the review... so. Ah, alright. I enjoyed this anime a lot. Colourful, full of romance, stories and laughs.\n
As with Yamato... well, she's a great girl. And the anime focus on Taeko more than her. Although she's a fantastic girl. Full of sweet and love and cute things. (Classic shoujo main female character).\n
Side characters are ok. All were fine!\n
Art and sound were ok too. Shoujo anime tend to be more colourful and this one makes not exception. Sounds too were more... cute and soft.\n
So i enjoyed this anime a lot! Full 8 for it!\n
(I'll spend some few words for Sunakawa: he's great. A golden friend. He's always on Taeko's side and i think he will always be.)\n

Are you sick and tired of clichés and harem shows? Do you want a romance that is actually good, not the repetitive romcom that goes absolutely nowhere and sacrifices everything for the jokes? Then Ore Monogatari is for you. This anime is not perfect, but it's far better than the bulk of cheap romcoms.
The comedy is surprisingly good, giving a ton of good laughs without pulling the classic black comedy that has to make characters suffer or be humiliated in some way. There is no clichéd bromatic foil that retarded and has to take the fall just to prove how normal the main character is.


And there is no harem. Harem is a plague that has infected anime for a long time, and any show that manages to keep it at bay deserves respect. There are beta couples, which is fresh air in the genre that has gotten so stale with main characters that have horribly unattractive personalities but somehow are supreme chick magnets to the point where nobody else seems to be in a relationship because they've monopolized every girl yet still won't act on it. Another reviewer called it "Nisekoi without the harem" as if it were a bad thing. I'd say removing the harem is an improvement to most if not all anime.


As for progression, it might not have the timeline of Code Geass, but saying there is no progression is just false. Compared to the classic romcoms that have tainted anime for such a long time, with 20+ episodes of nothing but unresolved sexual tension, I consider a show where somebody gets hitched by the end a major achievement. To a show where they not only hitch the characters before the end, but actually continue with the story, I give my applause. Too many shows refuse to hitch their characters as if afraid the fans would be pissed and try to burn the studio down.


Overall, Ore Monogatari is definitely part of the 8-9 score category on MAL, not a masterpiece, but definitely something far above average and recommendable to most people. The mix of comedy in romance is far better done that most other romcoms and despite its various flaws it deserves a solid 9, or if you're really critical, at least an 8, but anything less is not doing it justice.

When I review anime, a 7 is a 70% which means the anime was average but nothing special. I noticed most people would say that was worth a 5, or a 50%, but that is an F. If an anime didn't have any obvious flaws other than being nothing special, then I don't think it failed. So please read my reviews with this in mind. This is why most of my ratings seem on the high end. If I enjoyed it enough to finish it, it should be getting a C, not any lower.
Ore Monogatari!! was an anime that had caught my eye ever sinceI first saw it released because of its beautiful art style and unique twist on romance. In the end, it really reminded me of Lovely Complex, and that may be one of the reasons I enjoyed it as much as I did.


Story(6/10)

Aside from the unique concept of a less attractive man falling in love with a cute girl, this was pretty ordinary for a romance. There wasn't too much story, and not much ever really happened. I will say that this doesn't really take too much away from the show, though. In the end it is a romcom anime, so you really shouldn't expect it to have some spectacular story behind it. 


Art(8/10)

I believe that this is the strongest point of Ore Monogatari!! When I initially began watching it, I was worried about the characters being drawn with lips, but it works surprisingly well. Overall the soft pastel colors really capture the atmosphere, and the quality of the animation itself is really solid. On top of that, the eyes are really excellent, and just have so much life to them. 


Sound(6/10)

This is pretty much my standard as far as sound is concerned. The voice acting was nice, and never noticeably poor for any characters. However, the music wasn't really memorable. The music was never noticeably poor, but it wasn't noticeable excellent either. That is probably the best way to describe it. That intro is really wonderful, though.


Character(7/10)

I really enjoyed the characters, but I was hoping to see a little more development. None of the characters ever seemed to change besides Takeo, who came to understand relationships a little more during the series. I was wishing to see a little bit more work, though. On that note, I can't rate the characters any lower because I just loved them all. I was rooting for each and every one, and enjoyed their presence on screen.


Enjoyment(8/10)

This is really where the anime hits a home run. I couldn't help but smile at how sweet the whole thing was. I was always interested in how the relationship would develop and what twist the next episode would bring. What really helped it along was the comedy, though. The comedy was never dirty or vulgar. It had this innocence to it that accented the show so perfectly. It was all very easy to watch, and a nice way to end the day.


In the end Ore Monogatari!! really isn't anything revolutionary, but I do think it is something special. The atmosphere is just really sure and the tone is excellent. I can really recommend this to just about anyone that I know. Th only people I would warn away from this is anyone who dislikes romance or a plot that never really goes anywhere. But, why are you even here if that is the case?

Out there, somewhere, there is a guy who is just right for you. For some girls, that guy won't be the most attractive; in fact, some people may compare the guy you love with a gorilla. Even then, you still love that gorilla, and that is never going to change. With that being said, I've been interested in the Ore Monogatari manga since even before the anime was announced, so when the anime was announced, I automatically planned to watch it. All I can say is, watching this anime as it aired had to be one of the best decisions I ever made.
Ore Monogatari!! isabout a guy named Takeo Gouda, who is a giant guy - no exaggeration a here, he's HUGE - with a giant heart - no exaggerations here, either. However, the girls don't like him; instead, they want his good-looking best friend, Makoto Sunakawa. One spring day, in his first year of high school, he saves a girl, Rinko Yamato, from being molested by a pervert, and he fell in love with her IMMEDIATELY. However, as Takeo thinks, Yamato, like all of the other girls, likes Sunakawa.


....Or does she?


What I'm about to say is probably going to be a spoiler, so if you want to read this review without any spoilers, please skip this paragraph. Okay, so it turns out, Yamato actually loves Takeo, and the two of them, with a little push from Sunakawa, end up being a couple by the end of episode.... 3! Out of 24! Normally, in romance anime, the couple doesn't actually get together until towards the end or even at all. Thus, it's nice to see a romance cliché turned around, and we can actually see them as a couple. Takeo himself isn't the kind of protagonist you'd normally see in a romance anime, either, so that's a new one.


The story in Ore Monogatari is a mix of slice-of-life and drama. Although other people may disagree with me, I liked seeing both parts of the story through and through. I also liked a lot of the characters, and I loved seeing how they grew. Truthfully, though, the three stand-out characters are, of course, the three main characters, Takeo, Yamato, and Sunakawa. As I said before, Takeo isn't the kind of protagonist you'd normally see in a romance anime. I meant that appearance-wise, but maybe I mean that personality-wise, too. Most love interests in shoujo anime are total pricks; Takeo is absolutely not a prick, so it was nice. Takeo also had a lot of moments that just made me crack up laughing. Then, we've got his love interest, Yamato. I must say, Takeo's a lucky guy; Yamato is such a sweet girl, and it's clear that she really cares about her boyfriend.


Then, we've got Sunakawa, Takeo's best friend. At first, it's questionable as to why Takeo and Sunakawa are friends, but as the series goes by, the reason becomes clearer and clearer. Sunakawa truly cares about Takeo, and he's even willing to give up his own happiness for him. That is selflessness at its finest, and I really loved his character. Of course, Sunakawa's hot, too; as a girl, there's no way I can deny THAT.


The animation in Ore Monogatari is very colorful and overall quite solid. The character designs were quite good, as well. Truthfully, the voice acting isn't always on-point, but at least Takuya Eguchi didn't completely screw up his voice role as Takeo like I thought he would. The ED, "Shiawase no Arika", is quite a nice song, and it's very nice to listen to. However, it cannot compare to the OP, "Miraikei Answer", which I just love to DEATH.


Overall, Ore Monogatari is a massively great anime; in fact, it's a borderline-10/10. If you're tired of most of the clichés that most romance anime have, I would definitely recommend this one. I don't exaggerate when I say that this is a love story that all should enjoy!

First time review, so here we go.
Ore Monogatari!! has enjoyable things to look for in a romance anime. Want a love story devoid of drama and has so much vanilla, it'd overdose you on sugar? Then this show is for you and your cavities. 
Enter Gouda Takeo, the lumbering hulk of a protagonist. Meet also Sunakawa Makoto, the friend/wingman extraordinaire and the primary love interest/casual baker extraordinaire, Yamato Rinko. Despite his huge and intimidating presence, Takeo is a nice guy. The story delves mostly in his interactions with Rinko and how it buds over time, with him obtaining expert advice from Makoto and friends anddoing masculine, muscular, manly stuff that you wouldn't normally see other male protagonists do. It forms a soothing core as the story as he acts nice and friendly to everyone. It's a simple procedure, but I think works well because of one other thing.


The true core of the anime comes from the art and animation. Madhouse never fails to deliver, but there's something else to it. The quality starts to pop out in really small moments when Takeo and Rinko are together, highlighting them with great timing. It's moments like these where I enjoy the show the most and works well with a story devoid of over-the-top drama. The excitement wore off a bit as the series progressed, but I couldn't stop myself from smiling every episode. It's easy for any show to get a few laughs in... rarely does a show deliver constant enjoyment from beginning to end without any stops in between. 


Overall, this anime carries a few gems that other shows don't quite have. If you want a simple romance story and take things easy, this show is definitely for you.

Unlike most love stories that involve 2 characters seeing if they’re meant for each other. This anime takes a different approach, where it explores on the actual relationship of the characters through the dating. But let’s make the 2 lovers very different from one another. 
(The video review is up on my channel, here is the written)
Story - 9/10
The entire premise of the plot is can we get two completely different looking characters and make them a couple. And so comes in Takeo Gouda a very big looking scary guy. But he is quite the softy, he is a really nice guy, and a lotof people just get the wrong idea about him. He just can’t seem to get a girl because of his appearance, in fact most of the girls he falls for, all end up wanting to date his more handsome friend, Makoto Sunkawa, but even his friend has no interest in the girls that fall for him. So Takeo has a history of always failing in finding someone to like him, until he met Rinko Yamato, who he saved from a molester on a train. Now initially Takeo with his mind thinking a girl as good as her cannot fall for him, and mistakenly thinks she has fallen for his friend, he’s goal is to get them together. But let’s scratch that, because after a few episodes in, everything is confessed, and Takeo and Rinko change their relationship status from ‘single’ to ‘in a relationship’ with each other.


I love the premise of the story, it’s different to what we are used to seeing. At first it may look rather standard, with just the fact that the characters look completely different to each other. It is not a simple story of can the boy get the girl. It’s a story about their relationship, and how they build their relationship. One big common theme, is being able love someone in the inside. Because it did feel like the relationship came a bit fast, but then it left room for the characters to learn more about their other half. Even though the story is played out very well, through the characters, there are times in the plot where it felt unnecessary or just a distraction. Also there are times where small monologue text pop up on screen, and it’s kind of annoying you have to pause during those times to read them clearly. Some story plots didn’t feel like they made an impact later on. But regardless it is a beautiful story about two lovers learning more about each other. 


Characters - 9/10


The main protagonist is Takeo Gouda, a big scary looking high schooler, who obliviously scares almost everyone he sees. But he is gentle and kind, as he always puts others before him, as he tends to help people all the time without a second thought, never asking anything in return. He is one of the biggest bro’s in anime. Over the course of the anime, Takeo gets a lot of development as he learns, more about himself, because he usually doubts himself just because of his appearance, but he learns how to get along with more people and grows more confidence, in his relationship with Yamato. Albeit is quite dense, so the development takes quite a bit of time.


The other half of this relationship is Rinko Yamato. She looks cute and innocent, but she is just awkward. She fell for Takeo at first glance after he saved her from a molester, but due to Takeo being quite dense, their relationship started off awkwardly. However after the misunderstanding, she of course becomes his girlfriend. Rinko is the type of person who always feels guilty for not return something in return after being helped, and since Takeo always seems to find a way to help her, she always bakes him cakes afterwards. Her development goes at the same pace as Takeo, as it is about their relationship. However she realises Takeo, is quite dense, and accepts that, because she knows how much the people around him are important to him, so she is very patient with him. But as the story goes on the more development we see from her, and the more she starts showing herself.


The other main character of the show, that needs some attention for being the best bro, wingman and best third wheeler, is Makoto Sunkawa or also known as Suna. He is a calm, charming, charismatic and kind individual, who rarely shows a lot of emotion, more a kuudere I guess. He like Takeo puts other before him, as he is always looking out for Takeo, as always rejecting the girls that ask him out, because he knows Takeo likes them. He also helps Takeo hook up together with Yamato. He gets small development however, only towards the very end do we see some change, it’s because he is always focused on helping Takeo, hence being the biggest bro and third wheel in anime. 


Even though I love all the characters in their own way, it did feel like the characters were always just in the way of Takeo and Yamato. Because they’re time on screen are interesting, but they don’t really add much to the overall plot in general. Its more played out as how does Takeo and Yamato, react to this certain character’s experiences, and unfortunately, even for how interesting some are, they are really never seen again for the rest of the series. However this story is about the relationship between Takeo and Yamato, and I love almost every interaction they have with the other characters, and how the other characters help with their relationship. However, it does feel like every character is sort of nice to them, regardless. There is not much variety in their actions. 


Animation and Sound - 7/10, 8/10


The art style uses a lot of bright colours and lighting, to really show off the soft sided part of this show. The animation itself is fine, it’s nothing too special. If there is one thing, that is really noticeable with some of the designs, it’s the cake designs that Yamato makes during the show, they look amazing. Now Takeo and Yamato are 2 characters that really stand out, because they look completely different from each other, but they look different from everyone else. To honest, most of the character designs are quite similar. Just because you have one character that looks completely different, doesn’t mean, that every other character should be similar looking to make him feel left out even more. And some of the characters look off. But for the most part the scenery really does a good job of setting the mood.


The soundtrack is rather nice, it does a good job of setting the scene and its really nice to listen to. There are some very cute tracks and some very dramatic tracks which really adds to the majority of the comedy in the anime. The opening song is very nice to, setting up the show. The ending is quite a slow song, that does it job. The voice acting is great too, Takeo and Yamato’s voices are completely different to everyone else and it just shows how much different these characters are. 


Enjoyment - 9/10


I really loved watching this show, its cute and interesting. It is refreshing to watch a story about the relationship and moving forward rather than the wait to see if two characters can get together. The comedic moments are really entertaining, and are huge benefit to the show. The story is very touching and cute and its cleverly done. All the character interactions were entertaining, because of the majority of the reactions are completely over exaggerated. And no matter you’re always routing for the happy couple to solve their problems and further than relationship, than it already has. Yes there is some distractions along the way, but those distractions are enjoyable to watch as well, because sometimes other characters need some spotlight. Something to keep in mind, is that some of the jokes are re-used quite often.


Verdict - 8.5/10


For the story, I give it a 9, because the concept is really unique and they pull it off very well. The story touching and cute, and really well done. It does tend to get distracted here and there. But the plot is really enjoyable.


For the animation and sound, I give it a 7 and 8. The art suits the themes and the animation is fine as well, not great though. The majority of the characters however just look to similar to each other. The soundtrack does a great job of complimenting each scene and they are nice to listen to. The opening song is really good, the ending could be better buts not too bad.


For the characters I give them a 9. I love the relationship and development between Takeo and Yamato. Every character interactions helps build their relationship and there a lot of interesting characters. I just wished they were shown more after later on during the series, rather than being forgotten.


For my own personal enjoyment, I give it a 9. I love watching just about everything in this anime. The character interactions and story was well done. I was just routing for this couple to all the way to build their relationship. There are a lot of cute and funny moments in the anime, even though it gets distracted from time to time, those moments are enjoyable.


So for the overall score after rounding it up, I give My Love Story!! A 8.5/10. I recommend this anime to people looking for a good romantic comedy, it’s nice that the story is all about relationship building rather than gaining the confidence to ask each other out.

A romance anime of a new context which is good to watch and has got enjoyable moments too. This is a type of anime where you'll get a knowledge that one should never judge a book by it's cover. When I heard about this anime than at a instant I wanted to watch it but when I watched it; I found it not as good as I expected. Some moments reached to my expectation and some didn't. The first 3-4 episodes are very much interesting than the rest and other 13-14 episodes are good enough to watch but 24 episodes are too much for thisanime. The story line seems to be exaggerated just to show how good the character is.


The theme of this anime is to show that looks is not what matters in love; heart is the thing that needs to be beautiful and pure is love. A bad-ass looking guy named Takeo is not very popular in front of the school girls because any girls wants to make her friends jealous by the looks of her boyfriend. Beyond his looks, Takeo is a good guy from heart. He keeps other people feeling before him and let his feelings go for others happiness. But every girl doesn't want the face of their boyfriend to be sexy and charming, some just look for good heart. In the anime we find some girls who falls for Takeo because he is a good man.


*SPOILER ALERT*

Takeo has a childhood friend named Suwa who is very hot and every girls in the school likes him. In the first we see that Takeo loves a girl but the girl confesses her love to Suwa and Suwa kindly rejects her love. Takeo could not know why Suwa rejected her because he thought that looks is what matters but on the other hand Suwa rejected the girl because he didn't like backstabbers or one who talks bad behind their back. Yamato is  cute girl who was being harassed in the train and Takeo protects her. He falls for her at first glance but he develops a misunderstanding that she loves Suwa for being handsome. On the end of 4th episode Yamato and Takeo becomes one and the rest of the story is to show how good Takeo is from the heart and how bad the world thinks about him.


There are some funny parts in this anime too. Every time Takeo says "I Love Her" is kind of funny and I couldn't hold it and burst out laughing. There are some emotional parts too; when Takeo keeps his feelings back of others just to keep them happy. The story is good and new but overall when you see it than it's got not so good comedy and romantic scenes. So the anime is fair for me.

Ore Monogatari is an anime that actually starts out better than most shoujo animes I have watched, but also fall flat quicker and flatter than the rest that unfortunately I had to drop it halfway through the anime.
Story: the synopsis of Ore Monogatari describe the anime the best, and it all concluded in the first 3 episodes. Or to put it in another way, it both makes sense and is completely misleading at the same time. There is nothing that's worth calling a plot/story in the anime starting from ep 4. Instead it is a repetitive circle of sugary sweet romance and laughable comedy. Itis not bad, but it makes you feels like eating exactly 1 type of sweet dessert for breakfast, lunch, teatime, dinner and then sneak some into your bed to continue eating on bed. 


Art: The art is great, as expected from a shoujo anime. Our main character Takeo is described as weird looking and somewhat ugly, but the art is still able to make him really likeable. His best friend Suna and girl friend Yamato arts are very good, especially with Suna's hair and Yamato's facial espression. 


Sound: the sound is good, relaxing and fit a slice of life anime, and the theme songs are also good. I really like the ED. 


Characters: the characters are generic with Suna and Takeo swap place for usual anime tropes of MC best friend and love interest. But because the main characters are perfectly good, they dont seems to have development character-wise. That is yet another part that make the anime boring real fast. Their relationship is also wholesome. Suna with the usual MC characteristic should have some development, but unfortunately he isnt MC.


Enjoyment: Even though their relationship is really enjoyable, repetitive kills the show real quick. The anime is better if there is only 13 eps


In conclusion, this anime deserves a solid 7, even though it is not that bad (below 8 is bad to my scale), I cant give any anime that I had to drop higher score.

There's his best friend (Sunakawa) who is prettymuch the opposite of Takeo. All the girls love him and he is shorter and less intimidating. Throughout the series, girls see him as the most beautiful person they have ever seen.\n
Then, theirs Takeos girlfriend (Yamato Rinko) who is a sweet girl that falls in love with Takeo after he helped her. I recommend that anybody who likes to watch nice, romantic series should definitely watch this series.\n
This is quite a long review but to be honest, I made this review as short as I could due to the fact that I would have probably, eventually spoiled the series.

In all honesty, reviewer scores are irrelevant. Any anime with an overall rating of more than 8.0 (based on the overall votes) is always worth a watch. 
If you enjoy an innocent, naive and pure rom com view of young love and relationships - you will love Ore Monogatari!!. It is an uplifting tale with occasional touching scenes but it is definitely not a tear jerker by any means. It has great comedy based on the innocence and naivette of it's 2 main characters Takeo Gouda and Rinko Yamato, with the straight man and world's best bro Makoto Sunakawa.
Every episode is generally filled with sweetnessand light. All 3 main characters are just really nice people. Some complain that they are too one dimensional and that occasionally the jokes wear thin because they play on the innocence of Takeo too much. However in my view - we watch this show for precisely that reason. This anime is classic escapist fare, capturing the beauty and intensity of young love while still touching on themes such as being judged on appearances, unrequited love, dealing with jealousy and building relationships.


*Minor spoiler*

One point of difference is how the 2 leads form their relationship early in the series, rather than typically dancing around the issue agonisingly for 24 episodes before just holding hands or kissing in the finale. At least in this anime, it establishes this point quickly before moving on. I really appreciated this, having watched things like Kaichou wa Maid sama, ouran host club and teen romantic comedy SNAFU - which basically tortured the audience into submission by the main characters idiocy in not recognising the relationship early. At least in this one, they moved on to explore the actual relationship itself.


Artwise - in general it is colourful with a pleasing palette as you'd expect in a cheerful anime. Above all else, no one can watch this anime and feel depressed because each episode is just so well constructed to end with an uplifting message. 


Sound - I really enjoyed the soundtrack. Some have complained about the lack of presence of the music but I disagree because I thought the piano pieces which were themes of the 2 leads just fit the mood so well. I loved Clannad and Clannad AS - if you enjoyed Jun Maeda style compositions, you'll enjoy this sound track without question.


Enjoyment - When you watch anime, it helps if you understand what you want out of it. This anime is just a breath of fresh air in that it has no pretensions to explore the tragedy of human relationships nor the darkness that lurks in human hearts. The characters are all nice, there are no enemies, no villains or baddies. There are some awesome comedic scenes and some moments you just want to say 'kawaii!' (the practice kiss is one of the best laugh out loud scenes I've seen in a while!).


Overall - If you are looking for a change of pace in summer 2015 anime, I believe this anime fits the bill. Its a happy, cheerful and inspiring story which while simple does not fail to entertain and touch the heart. The characters are very relatable and you can't help but root and feel for them. This is definitely one of the highlights so far of the summer 2015 season.
